title: powers-handed-tracey-logan-emergency-scottish-borders-council-meeting
story: TRACEY Logan has been handed temporary control of Scottish Borders Councildecisions.In an emergency full council meeting, held on March  through video-conferencing, elected members agreed that meetings should be cancelled until September  to "minimise social contact during the coronavirus outbreak".In the meantime, decisions will be made, where possible, by Ms Logan.The proposal was moved for approval by council leader Shona Haslam and seconded byTweeddale East representativeStuart Bell, before being supported by all  members present, according to a council spokesperson.A section of the proposal read: "There is a risk that, should Council and committee meetings continue in their present form, coronavirus will spread wider in the community."Council business, including decision-making, must however continue so that there is least impact on service provision."By allowing greater flexibility in the decision-making processes, the Council can be confident that it will be able to carry out its s in a way that creates least risk to public health."Any meetings which must take place will be conducted using video-conferencing technology.

title: eildons-named-one-uks-best-summer-walks
story: A hike over the Eildons has been named one of the best summer walks in the UK.Travel website Wanderlust has drawn up a list of the seven top routes to tackle in the warmer months.And a traipse up the Eildons, near Melrose, emerged as one of the favourites.In an article published on March , Heather Moat praises the seven-mile walk for its offering of "panoramic vistas".She writes: "Come in late summer when the heather is in full bloom on the slopes, bag the three peaks and explore the abbey town of Melrose on the River Tweed before following St Cuthbertrsquos Way back to your starting point."Among the other locations mentioned in the Wanderlust guide are Anglesey in Wales, Durdle Door in Dorset and Rudyard Lake in Staffordshire.

title: douglas-crawford-reflects-melrose-festival-cancellation
story: DOUGLAS Crawford has been volunteering as a dog-walker as he digests the cancellation of this years Melrose Festival.Speaking to the Border , Douglas described his disappointment upon learning he will not act as Melrosian in .But he revealed his current focus is helping the community as it confronts coronavirus.Reflecting on the cancellation, he said: "Im obviously gutted to hear the news but given the circumstances itrsquos the right decision."Douglas had been due to keep alive a family tradition by leading proceedings in June, his brother Donald having been the latest member of the Crawford clan to appear as Melrosian.However, it will now likely be another year before the ex-Merchiston student takes a bow alongside Harry Fletcher and Ben Magowan, left-hand and right-hand man.Douglas said: "I hope to be able to do it next yearpossible, but at the moment nothings been confirmed as wersquore all currently focusing on how we can help the community in Melrose at this time."I know both Ben and Harry were equally disappointed as well, but they are definitely looking forward to fulfilling their duties next year."The ex-Melrosians Association has this week been going out into the community to offer help.Douglas said: "The ex-Melrosians Association have volunteered their services, and Irsquove been helping with some requests that have come into the rugby club, like dog walking etc."I think chairman Rob Moffat has been doing his bit delivering fruit and veg."The Braw Lads Gathering in Galashiels, the Selkirk Common Riding, and the Beltane Festival in Peebles have all been postponed until , but no principals had been announced for any of those events.In a statement on Thursday, March , organisers of the Braw Lads Gathering said: "In line with the advice from the Government, we have taken the unfortunate decision to cancel this years Braw Lads Gathering in its entirety."Selkirk Common Riding committee added: "The foregoing decision was made after very full and careful consideration of the current public health crisis and the need to play our part in endeavours to suppress the transmission of the invisible beast."The Borderland, over the centuries, has prevailed through war and pestilence and yet here in , we have another battle on our hands."Our cherished traditions, our heritage, demand that we plan with force and determination of mind to bounce back next year with even more vigour than before. Meanwhile, we in Selkirk are well forward in planning for the Common Riding in June ."

title: galashiels-pub-shut-first-time-ever
story: A LONG-SERVING pub landlord in Galashiels closed his doors for the first time ever on the eve of virus restrictions being introduced.Salmon Inn owner Ian Calder had always kept thirsty punters well-watered during his -plus years in charge - even on Christmas Day.But the -year-old took the dficult decision to shut for the foreseeable future shortly before the formal ban was announced on March .Mr Calder said: ldquoI really donrsquot knowit closed during the war. There might have been an odd day, but this is new territory.Mr Calder, believed to be the townrsquos longest-serving publican, runs the Bank Street premises with his we Helen and family.He told the Border : ldquoWe took the decision [to close] before the prime minister told everybody to shut.ldquoWe were just awfully concerned about our staff and customers and itrsquos one of those things that had to be done. We had to shut down for everybodyrsquos sake.Mr Calder said he could not bear the thought of visiting the pub the following day, such were his emotions at the time.ldquoI couldnrsquot go down to the pub on the Saturday - you just get yourself upset, said the grandfather.Mr Calder went on to outline the strength of his devotion to the pub, a business he regards as offering a ldquoservice to everybody.He said: ldquoEvery single day of the year wersquore open. Christmas Day is a bit of a joke because Irsquom the one thatrsquos doing the bar, serving from .pm until .pm.ldquoI wouldnrsquot have any of the staff or the family doing it and itrsquos amazing the amount of guys who come for draught beer before going home for tinned beer.Mr Calder is preparing himself for a considerable stint of time off and is currently self-isolating alongside we Helen, who suffered from sepsis last year.Reflecting on the pub closure, Mr Calder said: ldquoItrsquos sad for business and itrsquos sad for customers because for quite a lot of your customers itrsquos their day out, itrsquos their night out.The Salmon Inn recently joined forces with Pavilion Cinema manager Andrew Poole to launch a campaign encouraging Borders residents to purchase gt vouchers for use when businesses re-open.Michelle Douglas, Mr Calderrsquos daughter, said: ldquoItrsquos not just me and Andrew -  per cent of places now offer vouchers of some sort.Ms Douglas added that she expects pubs will be prepared for ldquoone hell of a party when theyto trading.

title: britons-left-dark-covid-19-precautions-returning-peru

frontline staff quickly.Some , people are currently in hospital in England, with , of those in London and , in the Midlands, where hospital admissions are accelerating.Prof Powis said the overall signs were that the ldquoGreat British public were heeding social distancing advice and reducing contact.Turning specically to the number of infections, Prof Powis told reporters at the daily Westminster press briefing: ldquoWe have had a rise in the number of new UK cases but recently there is a little bit of plateau.ldquoItrsquos really important not to read too much into this.vw,vw,px, px"ldquoItrsquos early days, wersquore not out of the woods, wersquore very much in the woods.ldquoThe number of infections is not rising as rapidly as it once was.ldquoSo green shoots, but only green shoots and we must not be complacent and we must not take our foot off the pedal.Prof Powis said the rate of hospital admissions was still increasing, as was expected at this stage of the epidemic.However, he saidthe number of infections started to drop, then in the next few weeks the ldquohope was that the number of admissions would also begin to fall.vw,vw,px, px"It comes as NHS title: psni-pauses-legacy-investigations-preparation-coronavirus-surge
story: Investigations into incidents in the regionrsquos troubled past will be paused amid the coronavirus crisis, Northern Irelandrsquos chief constable has announced.Simon Byrne has also announced the introduction of spit and bite guards for some officers on the frontline.The chief constable announced the temporary changes in a video posted on the PSNIrsquos Twitter feed on Tuesday.An update on temporary changes to @PoliceServiceNIoperations as part of the response to #COVID, the service will continually update @NIPolicingBoardon our procedures and work with @PONIPressOfficeto enhancepublic confidence. Please #StayHomeStaySafehttps:t.co cpvmKqHbxGmdash Simon ByrneMarch , He said officers and staff working on legacy were being transferred to bolster numbers as police worked to resume normal service amid the pandemic.Mr Byrne said that over the last weekend officers dealt with more than , calls which included domestic abuse incidents and missing people.ldquoWe have taken the decision to temporarily suspend all legacy investigations and release the officers and staff to provide immediate resilience to the PSNIrsquos critical policing s, he said.ldquoWe of course understand that this will be dficult for the families that have lost loved ones and itrsquos important to say that we recognise the continuing distress this decision will cause to many people who have suffered as a result of the Troubles.ldquoThis is a temporary measure and we will keep our decision under review as the current situation develops.The PSNIrsquos legacy unit is dealing with more than , unresolved cases.The chief constable also announced that spit and bite guard equipment was being made available to some officers for their protection.There have been several incidents of police officers being spat or coughed at by people claiming to have Covid-.The guards, made of mesh and plastic and placed over the head of a person who is threatening to spit or bite officers, were to be deployed in custody suites, it was announced last week.Mr Byrne said their use will be in line with human rights, videoed where possible, and the circumstances referred to the Police Ombudsman.ldquoGiven the unique and exceptional circumstances we face, I intend to make spit and bite guard equipment temporarily available to those dedicated Covid officers and those using cell vans, as well as people working in custody suites, he said.The representative body for police officers, the Police Federation, described the redeployment from the legacy branch as ldquounavoidable and understandable.vw,vw,px, px"Police Federation chairman Mark Lindsay Chairman Mark Lindsay said the redeployment will provide ldquomuch-needed resilience.ldquoI fully understand that for many victims of terrorism who seek information and closure, this will be a disappointing development.ldquoHowever, when the PSNI needs to maximise the number of officers for duty during this Covid- crisis, this decision is both understandable and unavoidable, he said.ldquoThis doesnrsquot mean that examining cases from the past will be forgotten. It simply means that the policing pressures of the here and now are so demanding that it requires the redeployment of all available officers.ldquoThis redeployment will provide much-needed resilience. Of course, what it also reflects is the fact that we are seriously under-resourced by several hundred officers and at this critical time, this glaring shortcoming is exposed..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: PSNI pauses legacy investigations in preparation for coronavirus surge

title: duo-spend-isolation-recreating-famous-looks-mary-poppins-sir-elton-john

title: josh-taylor-reveals-opponent-first-defence-world-titles

title: coronavirus-classes-queen-margaret-university-postponed-next-week
story: The university, near Musselburgh, outlined their stance yesterdayand vowed to keep students and staff updated of any future developments.Dr Richard Butt, deputy principal, said: "Queen Margaret University is continuing to monitor closely and follow healthcare and Government advice from Health Protection Scotland."Our campus and halls of residence remain open. We will comply with advice from Health Protection Scotland and the Scottish Government and take any necessary stepswe are advised to do so in the future."The guidance on the website will be updated,required, by pm each day."Learning and teaching will move entirely online by next Monday .Dr Butt added: "We will be moving to delivering teaching online."Reduced face-to-face teaching will begin from Monday , and no face-to face teaching will take place from March  until further notice."If there are any changes to your classes in the week beginning March , information will be published on the Hub."Academic staff will decide how best to conduct teaching and learning activities, using a range of resources to best support students."Meanwhile, all undergraduate and taught postgraduate exams and assessments scheduled for next Monday, including those for the Semester  exam period , and reassessments scheduled for the end of July, will be delivered online or by other methods of alternate assessment.Assessment type will be guided by academic discipline and academic staff expertise.Students will be notied as early as possible about what online assessments mean in practice.Inidual Learning Plan Adjustments will also continue.Students wishing tohome can do so.Dr Butt added: "We understand that some students, particularly those from overseas, may be anxious and you may be considering ing home."If you do decide tohome, you will not be penalised for doing so."Whilst we are changing our mode of learning and teaching and taking measures to be responsive to an evolving situation, QMUrsquos campus will remain open."We have had no indication from Health Protection Scotland or the Scottish Government that we should close, and buildings, services and facilities will run as usual.Staff and students can be on campus and our library, specialist facilities, student services, refectory, the halls of residences and Studentsrsquo Union are also open."We will continue to monitor and comply with advice from Health Protection Scotland and take any necessary steps, including possible campus closure,we are advised to do so in the future. "Graduation ceremonies scheduled for July will also be rescheduled, most likely to autumn.

title: coronavirus-musselburgh-racecourse-hold-meetings-behind-closed-doors
story: This weekrsquos Racing Post Go North race day will be open only to racing connections and will be in line with the Scottish Government recommendation that no events of more than  people should be held in light of the coronavirusoutbreak.Those attending will be asked to sign a self-declaration form that they do not have a temperature or symptoms associated with coronavirus. Anyone who has pre-booked tickets for either March race day will receive a full refund.Musselburgh Racecourse general manager Bill Farnsworth said: "Behind closed doors racing will comply with the guidelines set out by the Scottish Government and a meeting of less than  people, which includes participants, connections and staff, will not add any additional stress to emergency services."The racing industry, like many other sectors, is facing unprecedented challenges and is fighting for its future. We are keen to do whatever we can to support jobs and to mitigate loss of income, and holding meetings behind closed doors seems a sensible approach."Racingrsquos governing body the British Horseracing Authorityearlier announced all racing in Scotland, England and Wales would take place without spectators and with attendance limits until March .Nick Rust, chief executive of the BHA, said: "Racecourses and racing yards are embedded in their local communities and we are acutely aware of our responsibilities to protect public health."The restrictions we are putting in place to close racing to spectators and limit attendees will reduce demand on public services. We also have a range of measures in place designed in response to the Governmentrsquos guidance on public health and we will continue to update these as appropriate."Musselburgh will review how racing may proceed for its popular Betway Easter Saturday Race Day on April  as the situation develops and will continue to follow all Government and NHS advice on best practice on containing the virus.Regular updates on the racecourse website and social media channels,will advise racegoers, owners and trainers on any material changes to scheduled race meetings.For more information, visit musselburgh-racecourse

title: council-petitioned-formally-adopt-masterplan-former-cockenzie-power-station-site
story: The plan, revealed in , outlines a potential future for the former Cockenzie Power Station site and was the result of a local authority consultation in  with communities and stakeholders surrounding the site.In the petition, Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council claims that three years after the consultation, East Lothian Council ldquocontinue to go against the wishes and aspirations of our communities and stakeholders by not formally adopting the masterplan, causing ision, unrest and anger.It says that the councilrsquos ldquounwillingness to act has resulted in a number of plans and proposals, including Skyrorarsquos rocket engine testing facility and Inch Capersquos plan to build a substation, the latter having been approved.It adds: ldquoThe masterplan is our communitiesrsquo vision for the Cockenzie site ndash which includes our communitiesrsquo green space, pathways and parklands.ldquoThe masterplan brings leisure, recreation, tourism, industry and jobs whilst protecting our coastal environment and heritage site.The masterplan includes the creation of office and retail jobs as well as an ldquoenergy quarter, which would bring renewable energy jobs to the site.It also includes a ldquopublic art installation similar to the Kelpies in Falkirk, spaces for festivals, markets and other events, and retains the Battle of Prestonpans site.A community council spokesperson said: ldquoCockenzie and Port Seton Community Council call on East Lothian Councilto do the right thing and formally adopt the masterplan, which came about through guidance from the Scottish Parliament public petitions committee in .ldquoAt that time, East Lothian Council asked the communities bordering the Cockenzie site for their views on the future of the site through a series of workshops and consultation events for the communities and stakeholders.ldquoELC asked the communities answered the outcome is the ELC Peter Brett Cockenzie Masterplan.The Cockenzie Masterplan not only captures the communitiesrsquo vision, it has the potential for upwards of , jobs and also aligns with NPF goals.ldquoOur communities will continue to ask ELC to be as good as their word at the time of our participation in the masterplan consultations ndash to formally adopt the masterplan so that a template exists for the site which clearly reflects the hopes, dreams and aspirations of our communities. Where green space and environment are respected, enhanced and sit alongside industry and energy at Cockenzie, as has been the case for decades and generations.ldquoHad ELC formally adopted the masterplan, Inch Cape would not be located on the coastal frontage of the site, but in Zone , the Energy Quarter, and our communities would not have had the ision and angst caused by the Skyrora proposal to test rocket engines in the midst of communities.ldquoThis week, we read that a large area of land in the Scottish Borders has been passed to the community at a cost to them of pound so that their aspirations for the future can be achieved.ldquoWe ask that ELC either formally adopt the Cockenzie Masterplan or follow that lead and gt the site to the communities.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWe recognise the importance of the sitersquos future and remain committed to working with and updating local stakeholders.ldquoThe former Cockenzie Power Station site has signicant potential for economic development and employment opportunities. The masterplan report ndash which reflects this and set out options for a mixed-use site ndash continues to be an important visionary document.ldquoSince its publication, Inch Cape Offshore Limitedhas received planning permission from Scottish Ministers to build onshore transmission works on part of the site.ldquoAlso, the National Planning Framework continues to include Cockenzie as a site of signicance for thermal energy generation.ldquoIt remains the case that we need to understand whether there are any implications for the site arising from the next National Planning Framework, as well as from potential future planning policy considerations and further technical work.ldquoWe see the masterplan report as one of a number of important considerations that will inform the councilrsquos input to the development plan process. The council is also determined that further technical work was required on the viability of port-related development.ldquoUnderstanding the full implications of all of this is key before the future of the whole site can be determined.The plan was originally drawn up by Peter Brett Associates, appointed by East Lothian Council.The petition can be viewed at change.org p east-lothian-council-petitioning-east-lothian-council-to-formally-adopt-the-cockenzie-masterplan

title: weightlifting-headteacher-earns-podium-position-international-event
story: Lynda Banks represented Great Britain at the European Masters Classic Powerlting Championships in France last Monday .The Cockenzie Primary School headteacher lted a whopping  kilogrammes across the three events in the age -,  kilogrammes category, to come home with two bronze medals from the competition in Albi, near Toulouse.Ms Banksrsquo powerlting prowess came about ldquoby pure chance.She had started training at a gym in Inverness when she was , with a view to being strong enough to complete a chin-up.That was successfully achieved and a love of deadlting followed, with the -year-oldrsquos first competition in Dumfries in .Within  months, she had a gold medal for deadlts as part of the British team.Ms Banks swapped Hilton Primary School in Inverness for East Lothian in October last year, the new head replacing Jacqui MacKinnon, who moved on to North Berwickrsquos Law Primary School.The headteacherrsquos positive mental attitude influences her approach to school leadership, and she has shared with schoolchildren in assembly her experiences competing.The Edinburgh resident said: ldquoOne of our school values is positivity.ldquoWhen I competed at the World Championships in Texas I pulled kg, which I hadnrsquot done before, and took overall third place in the world.ldquoHaving a positive attitude is so important.ldquoWe work to foster a sense of school achievement, with a wall where pupils and staff are encouraged to share a wide range of their achievements such as chanter, ing, rock climbing, so we can all celebrate them.The children also enjoy seeing her collection of medals, which she keeps in her office.Five days after making the move to Cockenzie Primary School and nursery, which is home to  pupils, Ms Banks was competing in the British Championships, retaining her title in her age and weight category for the fth successive year, and achieving three personal bests: squat .kg, bench press .kg and total kg, having deadlted kg, too.It was this performance that led to an invitation to take part in Team GB in Albi.The headteacher primarily trains in Edinburgh, although she has started attending Meadowmill Sports Centre, to help fit her training around her busy school schedule.She also works with a nutritionist and said: ldquoI want to be as strong as I can to compete and stay at a healthy weight.ldquoI eat healthily ndash I eat a lot of chicken, rice and porridge and drink plenty of water.ldquoHowever, I can still have cakeI want to!

title: coronavirus-residents-urged-keep-helping-east-lothian-foodbank
story: The foodbank, based in Tranent, provides food parcels to vulnerable members of the community.Candace Higgins, foodbank director, said the situation was changing ldquohour by hour, adding: ldquoWe are still operating as normal but certain protocols have been put in place when delivering food parcels.Volunteers making deliveries are now simply knocking on doors or ringing bells, rather than waiting for doors to be opened to them. The parcels can then be left in safe places, while, at the charityrsquos headquarters on Civic Square, ldquostringent cleanliness and health and safety rules are in place.Candace praised the local community for their continued support in making donations to the group.She said: ldquoWe are really benefiting from having such a fantastic community. Donations have gone up rather than down.However, she also issued a call for people to stop panic or bulk buying.She added: ldquoWe are running low on chopped tomatoes, long-le fruit juice, instant mash potato and tinned potatoes. In terms of household items, it would be the same things as everyone  is running low on ndash kitchen roll, toilet roll and baby wipes.The foodbank is staffed by volunteers and Candace said they anticipated a number of volunteers who are over the age of  would have to remain in their homes over the coming weeks, with a reduced schedule of deliveries. Instead, moves could be made to change the model to a pantry and larder model.The foodbank was visited at the end of last week by the countyrsquos MP, Kenny MacAskill, who met with  volunteers.He said: ldquoThe foodbank is a treasure, but the circumstances that have made these projects so important are the result of bad choices by successive Governments.ldquoItrsquos especially important now with the coronavirus pandemic that we continue to support our local foodbank to make sure those in crisis are able to have at least the comfort of a hot meal.

title: coronavirus-dunbar-civic-week-postponed
story: Dunbarrsquos Civic Week was due to take place from June  to  but the townrsquos community councillors have taken the tough decision to cancel the annual celebration amid fears surrounding coronavirus.George Robertson, chairman of the Civic Week planning committee, spoke to the Courier on Thursday, with the decision officially taken to cancel the event just days later.He said: ldquoThere are discussions taking place and it is very likely to be cancelled.ldquoThat is my recommendation to the community council and I am awaiting them to come back to me.Traditionally, Civic Week, which started in , features dozens of events, ranging from football tournaments to a cycle ride.The townrsquos leboat station opens its doors to visitors and live music is performed at The Battery, at the townrsquos harbour.Central to the event is the crowning of Dunbarrsquos Civic Week Queen, who is a randomly chosen female P pupil from the town.Mr Robertson said there were concerns that coronavirus would decimate the programme, which is already in the process of being drawn up.He said: ldquoYou cannot have a fun day or a parade with  people.ldquoA lot of people are going to be in lockdown.ldquoIt is a real blow and it could not have come at a worse time [the event was due to celebrate  years] but in the grand scheme of things, cancelling Dunbar Civic Week, like Wimbledon and Glastonbury, does not amount to a whole lot of grievance.ldquoI was quite anxious we made a decision.ldquoWe were discussing this before the school closure came about and we were due to have a draw on March  for the Royal Court.Mr Robertson, who is also a member of the townrsquos community council, said ldquoa lot of preparation had already gone into the event and thanked the work of volunteers Eileen Moore and Sanchita Patjoshi in pulling everything together.It remains to be seenthe event will be rescheduled for later in the year or simply resume in the summer of .Mr Robertson noted that attempting to hold the event later in the year created a number of other potential issues.No one knows when everyday events couldto normal in the wake of COVID-, while the children who are currently in P would have moved on to Dunbar Grammar School by the time the event could be held.This yearrsquos event was also due to mark the th anniversary of the granting of the Royal Charter to Dunbar.The Royal Charter was granted to Dunbar by King David the Secondin .This came about because Berwick-upon-Tweed was then in English hands and the lucrative revenues from the export of border wool was lost to the Scottish crown.The granting of a Royal Charter to Dunbar meant that this trade could now go via Dunbar and the port of Belhaven, and revenues revert to Scotland.The th anniversary was celebrated in grand style in  with the very first Dunbar Civic Week, and Civic Week has continued annually ever since.

title: alex-salmond-cleared-east-lothian-mp-says-resignations-required
story: Mr Salmond was on trial on  charges, which included charges of attempted rape and sexual assault.The jury retired to deliberate its verdict on Friday afternoon after a two-week trial but came to its decision today.The -year-old was found not guilty of  charges and not proven for another.In a post on Twitter, East Lothians MP Kenny MacAskill, a known ally of Mr Salmond, said he was ldquodelighted for the former First Minister, adding: ldquoSome resignations now required".

title: coronavirus-scotland-essentially-already-lockdown-businesses-told-close
story: Nicola Sturgeon also indicated that Scotland is essentiallyalready in ldquolockdown, but without it being enforced.She warned that people should remain at home ldquounless itrsquos absolutely essential to go out ndash while Scotlandrsquos chief medical officer, Catherine Calderwood, said that people can go out and exercise once a day but ldquoonly in small family groups.Ms Sturgeon said that the advice issued is ldquorules that we are expecting people to comply with and that businesses that cannot operate remotely should ldquoconsider closing or hibernating.She added: ldquoFor everyone, you must stay at home unless it is absolutely essential to go out. That includes working from home wherever possible.ldquoStay away from crowded places, even out of doors. When there are other people around, stay two metres distance from them.ldquoThat advice is for everyone but it is especially vitalyou are over , eligible for the flu vaccine or pregnant. At all times, follow the advice on washing your hands, using tissues and touching your face.Ms Sturgeon pleaded with businesses that have not yet closed their doors to the public.She said: ldquoIf you are not providing essential items like food and medicines, then please also close now.ldquoThere are still too many people across our country who are being expected to or are expecting to go to work as normal. That presents a serious and unnecessary risk of spreading the virus.Ms Sturgeon added that building sites and hair salons should also close to help in the efforts to suppress the coronavirus pandemic.She added: ldquoI know this is a dficult situation for businesses and I know dficult judgements are having to be made.ldquoI have therefore asked for additional guidance to be drawn up urgently by government for businesses that will make clear exactly what we are expecting of them and how they can make theright judgements on what is essential and whatis not essential.ldquoWe are pushing for and are very hopeful of seeing very seen, further measures to support freelancers, the self-employed and contract workers.ldquoIt should enable businesses to do the right thing for themselves and for their workers.Dr Calderwood said that it was important that people couldleeavetheir homes to exercise once a day for mental and physical wellbeing, but urged people to do it in small family groups to stop the spread of coronavirus.She said: ldquoPeople should go out once a day to exercise but donrsquot do it except in small family groups.ldquoWe are going to have to adapt to le in this new world. We are really in this for the marathon, not a sprint.The First Minister also indicated that Scotland and wider UK is essentially already in ldquolockdown as has been described in Italy and other countries ndash albeit without the enforcement.She said: ldquoIt is very possible that in the days to come, we will see more stringent measures be applied.ldquoIf we take a step back from the word lsquolockdownrsquo, and think about what all the components of that would be - asking people to stay at home and not go to work unless it isvitally essential, asking people not to go shopping unless itrsquos for food and medicine, asking people to keep their distance, not gather in crowds of people.ldquoThatrsquos essentially the elements of what you are seeing in other countries where it has been described as lockdown."I guess the missing bit that we may have to move tothe advice tells us itrsquos necessary, iswhether that is beingissued in a way of advice, although Irsquom being very clear we want people to treat it as rules, or whether there is more enforcement on that. I canrsquot rule that out.She added: ldquoAs First Minister, I will not hesitate to do what is necessary here. Irsquom not ruling anything out.ldquoWhat Irsquom being crystal clear on is that the public donrsquot have to wait for lockdowns or enforcement to do the right things.ldquoItrsquos within the ability of each and every one of us as citizens to do the right things now. Donrsquot wait for somebody to tell you - please do it.

title: coronavirus-east-lothians-coastal-car-parks-closed
story: Childrens play areas in the county have also been closed.East Lothian Council said the decision, which takes effect immediately,was taken due to "the escalating challenges posed by the coronavirus outbreak, the need to ensure appropriate social distancing between iniduals and to reduce the risk of cross-infection from contact surfaces".Monica Patterson, chief executive of East Lothian Council, said: ldquoFrom the outset of the coronavirus outbreak, we have been clear about the need to follow national health and government advice.ldquoAlthough we appreciate that the coastal car parks are popular with those who enjoy our fantastic local beaches ndash particularly during good weather ndash there are concerns about this presenting dficulty for people following social distancing advice at busy times."Itrsquos essential that people avoid gatherings at this time and keep two metres away from other people."Advice against non-essential travel is also in place.ldquoDue to the risk of cross-infection from contact surfaces, we have also reluctantly made the decision to temporarily close the councilrsquos childrenrsquos play areas. This relates specically to areas with play equipment rather than larger parks open spaces which have play areas within them.ldquoWhile we appreciate people will be disappointed, we believe these decisions are in the best interests of everyonersquos health and wellbeing as we respond to the unprecedented challenges presented by this outbreak.The closurealso appliesto the toilet and showering facilities at the car parks.The council is also urging people not to travel to access open space and coastal areas outwith the town or village they reside in, as this could speed up the spread of the virus area to area.The council stated: "Social distancing is key. Everyone should avoid congregating in large groups and stay at least two metres apart from others at all times."We would urge young people and their parents carers to be conscious of this."We would title: coronavirus-council-introduces-emergency-recess-procedures
story: The decision was made by the chief executive following consultation with the three political group leaderson the council.The decision means:All business undertaken during the emergency recess will be subject to reports to East Lothian Councilrsquos Membersrsquo Library, and a summary report will be presented to the next council meeting outlining all business undertaken.Chief executive Monica Patterson said: ldquoIn the view of the increasingly dficult situation arising from the coronavirus outbreak, after consultation with political group leaders, I have made the decision to invoke the COVID- emergency recess procedures.ldquoThe outbreak is presenting signicant and developing challenges to the delivery of public services.ldquoIt is essential that the councilrsquos focus is on continuing to take actions to sustain critical services as far possible, maximising the availability of our resources in as flexible a manner as possible.ldquoMore generally, we continue to follow national guidelines while implementing appropriate measures.ldquoIt is important that we continue to support each other and the communities we serve at this very dficult time.

title: coronavirus-new-changes-recycling-collections-recycling-centres-closed
story: Collection of both the green and blue recycling boxes will resume across East Lothian on each households normal calendar dates.That follows a previous change brought in on Monday which had seen green and blue recycling boxes still emptied on their usual day but, rather than both being emptied at the same time, the green box emptied on the first fortnight and the blue box the second fortnight.Now, both will be emptied together again.The council is also continuing to collect non-recyclable waste fortnightly, as per each households calendars.Brown bins for garden waste collections remain suspended until further notice, as had taken effect from Monday.A council spokesperson said: "If this situation changes due to staff shortages during the current coronavirus crisis, we will issue further updates via our website and social media. Please keep an eye out for these."Meanwhile, all four of the countys recycling centres are closed until further notice."We will update you as soon as that situation changes," the spokesperson added.

title: coronavirus-public-toilets-east-lothian-closed
story: East Lothian Council announced the decision to shut its public toilets this morning .The council operates  public toilets across the county, with about eight of them staffed.It said that staff working in the toilets would now be sent to carry out deep cleans on buildings such as the planned childrenrsquos hubs which will open this week to care for key workersrsquo children.Meanwhile, Councillor Norman Hampshire, the councilrsquos depute leader, urged people to work with the local authority as it does its best to provideessential services.He said: ldquoIf we are going to deal with the challenges we are all going to face, we all need to work together.ldquoEvery service the council provides to you and your community will be affected.ldquoThe council and every member of our staff will do all we can to help you and our communities get over the impact of the coronavirus and get your community le back to normal as quickly as possible.ldquoHowever, to do that we will need your support and understanding as we reduce or in some cases stop non-essential services in order to continue providing essential services to our most vulnerable.ldquoThe council will inevitably be working with fewerstaff so please understand that some things will stop and others will take longer than normal to deliver. ldquo

title: wetherspoons-boss-tells-staff-go-work-tesco-leaving-no-pay
story: After being forced to closehundred of pubs over the weekend to battle the spread of Covid-, Martin sent a video to staff members claiming that he would be relying on a Government grant to pay workers.However, the grant will not be available for well over a monthand Martin,who is reportedly worth over pound million, will not be covering staff wages until then.More than , workers have been left without a future pay date, unsure how they will be able to afford rent, bills or groceries.A letter from members of Wetherspoons staffOther companies, such as Costa Coffee, have guaranteed that staff will be paid for the next eight weeks despite also shutting their doors.The move came shortly after Martin claimed the global pandemic was nothing more than a "health scare" and that the closing pubs would be an "over the top" reaction.In the video sent to staff, in which Martin appears holding a mug, he stated that the need to close "puts everyone in a terrible position"."And I know youre all sitting there wondering what the hell is happening and over the weekend I had lots of phone calls with dferent people and were trying to sort it out as best we can in this highly unusual situation."The Wetherspoons bossthen encourages staff to go work at Tesco.He said: "I know that all our trade now has gone to supermarkets. Not only our trade, but the trade from cafeacutes, leisure centres, restaurants etc."So we have had lots of calls from supermarkets, Tesco alone want , people to join them. Thats half the amount of people who work in our pubs."Martin then says staff member have the option to leave rather than waiting for payments to begin - but theres no guarantee they would get their job back at a future date.He said: "If Im honest, I could say you can get the furlough payments and stay at home."If youre offered a job at a supermarket, many of you will want to do that. If you think its a good idea, do it."I can completely understand it. If youve worked for us before I promise we will give you first preferenceyou want to come back."I completely understandyou dont want to wait around for us to re-open but deeply appreciate your work."

title: coronavirus-buckfast-tonic-wine-ceases-production
story: The decision was "not taken lightly", its producers said.It follows Prime Minister Boris Johnson introducing a lockdown across the country last night and tellingall non-essential businesses to close.A statement read: "Given the unprecedented Covid- situation, we wanted to take time to update you on our position."With immediate effect our offices and production lines will temporarily close, this decision was not taken lightly, however we must act on the Governments advice."Our safety and wellbeing of our employees, and the wider community is of the utmost importance."We must play our part in helping to protect our NHS by asking our employees to stay at home."With the temporary closure, our distribution network will be freed up to play itrsquos part in delivering vital essential commodities across the United Kingdom at this time."Our production will commence as soon as we can. Thank you for your understanding."

title: new-website-lists-east-lothian-businesses-offering-delivery-take-out-services
story: North Berwick Community Council wanted to set up similar resource and was working with the local area partnership to do just that.Hilary Smith, chair of North Berwick Area Partnership, was, at the same time, speaking to David Turnbull, owner of Turnbulls Home Hardware store in North Berwick.David visited businesses in North Berwick before the lockdown asking for information about their current delivery and take-out options, which was then organised into a list.Judy Lockhart, chair of North Berwick Community Council, said: ldquoThen just by chance a man called Dan Appelbee messaged us. He lives in Musselburgh but has no connections to any community groups, he just wants to help East Lothian out.Dan suggested a website to collate all the information and offered his services to help put it together and www.weelocals was born.It now hosts information on all the shop home delivery and takeaway options in North Berwick but local businesses in East Lothianrsquos other towns and villages are being encouraged to add their own delivery information.Some in Aberlady, Cockenzie, Gullane and Dunbar have now done so too.Judy added: ldquoIrsquod encourage others to use it and add in their own information so that it is all in one easy to access place.ldquoIn Tesco, the next delivery slot isnrsquot until April  and some older residents donrsquot know where they can get stuff delivered locally.ldquoIt can also help sustain those businesses in that time.ldquoThe website has been really well received so far and it would be good to roll it out through the other towns.If any other businesses want to feature on the site, they should use this link: www.weelocals add-your-business

title: man-entered-ex-partners-home-rummaged-possessions
story: Graham Watt, , attended at the womans property at the townrsquos Trainers Brae and made his way inside.He then went through her belongings without the woman being at home between December  last year and January  this year.Watt also attended at the home when the woman was present and placed his foot in the front door, preventing her from closing it.Watt, of Melbourne Place, was in the dock at Edinburgh Sherf Court where he pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner towards the woman.Sherf Adrian Cottam decided to fine Watt pound and told him he could not contact the woman or enter the street she lived in for the next  months as part of a non-harassment order.Watt pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner by entering the property uninvited, going through the womanrsquos possessions, attending at the property and placing his foot in the door to prevent it from closing and repeatedly pushing against the front door at Trainers Brae, North Berwick, between December  last year and January  this year.

title: mot-tests-suspended-6-months-amid-coronavirus-lockdown
story: In the immediate aftermath of Boris Johnsons lockdown announcement, there were mixed messages about whether MOT tests would still be required.But the Department for Transport has now made it clear: no MOT tests will be needed for  months, effective March , to enable people to shop for necessities or continue travellingto work "where this absolutely cannot be done from home".Vehicles must still be kept roadworthy and garages will remain open for essential repairs.Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said: ldquoWe must ensure those on the frontline of helping the nation combat COVID- are able to do so.ldquoAllowing this temporary exemption from vehicle testing will enable vital services such as deliveries to continue, frontline workers to get to work, and people get essential food and medicine.ldquoSafety is key, which is why garages will remain open for essential repair work.If your MOT is due before March , you will still technically need to have a testyou need to driveit or park it on the street - but the DfT says it is working with police and insurers to "ensure people arent unfairly penalised for things out of their control".Other measures taken by the DfT due to the COVID- pandemic include the suspension of practical driving tests, along with annual testingfor lorries, buses and coaches, for up to  months.

title: coronavirus-prince-wales-tests-positive-condition
story: In a statement about the -year-olds health, Clarence House said: "The Prince of Wales has tested positive for coronavirus."He had been displaying mild symptons but otherwise remains in good health and has been working from home throughout the last few days as usual."What about Camilla - the Duchess of Cornwall The Duchess of Cornwall has also been tested but does not have the virus.Where are they both now It adds:"In accordance with Government and medical advice, the Prince and Ducheess are now self-isolating at home in Scotland [at Balmoral]."The tests were carried out by the NHS in Aberdeenshire where they met the criteria required for testing."It is not possible to ascertain from whom the Prince caught the virus owing to the high number of engagements he carried out in his public role during recent weeks."

title: contactless-payment-limit-increase-45---need-know
story: At the beginning of next month, the limit will change from pound to pound.Why is the change happening The move has been name to helpreduce physical contact with keypads on chip and pin machines due to the coronavirus crisis.It is hoped the increased limit will helpin the fight against Covid-.When will the change take place The British Retail Consortiumsaid the move would begin on April , , but warned that implementation in some shops may take longer.What has the British Retail Consortium said about this BRC head of payments policyAndrew Cregansaid: ldquoThe last contactless limit increase to pound took two years to implement but, given the extraordinary circumstances we face today, this new pound limit will be rolled-out from next week.ldquoSome shops will take longer to make the necessary changes, given the strain theyrsquore under. In the meantime, most customers can continue to make contactless payments for higher amounts using their smart phone.Coronavirus: the facts from the World Health Organisation and the NHSCOVID- is a respiratory illness that can affect lungs and airways. It is caused by a virus called coronavirus.The outbreak started in Wuhan in China in December  and it is thought that the virus, like others of its kind, has come from animals.As this is such a new illness, experts still arenrsquot sure how it is spread. But, similar viruses are spread in cough droplets. Therefore, covering your nose and mouth when sneezing and coughing, and disposing of used tissues straight away is advised. Viruses like coronavirus cannot live outside the body for very long.The NHS states that the symptoms are: a dry cough, high temperature and shortness of breath - but these symptoms do not necessarily mean you have the illness. Look out for flu-like symptoms, such as aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose and a sore throat. Itrsquos important to remember that some people may become infected but wonrsquot develop any symptoms or feel unwell.Washing your hands with soap and water thoroughly. The NHS also advises to cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or your sleevewhen you cough or sneeze put used tissues in the bin immediately and try to avoid close contact with people who are unwell. Also avoiding touching eyes, nose and mouth unless your hands are clean.As of Monday,March , the prime minister has put the UK into lockdown and instructed all citizens to stay at home. People can only leave their homes to exercise once a day, go shopping for food and medication, travel for medical needs or to care for a vulnerable person, and travel to work onlyessential. Police will be able to enforce these restrictions.All non-essential shops will close with immediate effect, as will playgrounds, places of worship and libraries. Large events or gatherings of more than two people cannot go ahead, including weddings and celebrations. Funerals can only be attended by immediate family. Children of separated parents can go between both parents homes.Anyone with a cough or cold symptoms needs to self-isolate with their entire household for  days.The Government has now instructed bars, restaurants, theatres and non-essential businesses to close and will review on a lsquomonth to monthrsquo basis. Schools closed from Friday, March , for the foreseeable future, and exams have been cancelled.The over-s or anyone who is vulnerable or living with an underlying illness are being asked to be extra careful and stay at home to self-isolate. People with serious underlying health conditions will be contacted and strongly advised to undertake "shielding" for  weeks.For more information on Government advice, please check their website.You should now avoid public places and any non-essential travel. Travel abroad is also being advised against for the next  days at least, and many European countries have closed their borders.Donrsquot go to your GP but instead call NHS  or look online at the coronavirus service that can tell youyou need medical help and what to do next.NHS  should be usedyou feel unwell with coronavirus symptoms, have been in a country with a high risk of coronavirus in the last  days oryou have been in close contact with someone with the virus.

title: man-spotted-trying-push-woman-car-wallyford
story: Paul Breslin was seen by a passing dog walker as he become involved in an incident with the woman in Wallyford in .Breslin was with another male as he tried to ldquoforce the woman into the front seat of the car at the villagersquos Wallace Gardens.A struggle between all three ensued and the woman was forced to scream out as Breslin attempted to get her into the vehicle.A second witness also saw the commotion at about am on a Sunday and, as she was ldquoconcerned for the female, she walked over to intervene.The woman who was being manhandled managed to make her way from the vehicle and two men subsequently got into the car and drove off.Police were contacted the following day and Breslin, of Carberry Court, was traced and arrested.The -year-old appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court, where he pleaded guilty to a heavily-amended charge.Solicitor Jonathan Campbell said that his client had been in an on-off relationship with the woman and that she had called him in the early hours of the morning looking for a lt home from a party she was attending.The lawyer said there had been ldquoincidents of infidelity between the pair and when Breslin arrived at the party he found she had changed her mind and decided to stay at the property.The woman then called Breslin a second time two hours later and, after he had gone to pick her up, she again ldquochanged her mind and attempted to open the car door as the vehicle was moving.As Breslin was struggling with her in a bid to get her back into the car at Wallace Avenue, that is when the witnesses arrived on the scene and saw the confrontation between the pair, the lawyer said.Mr Campbell said there had been ldquono abduction of the woman as originally libelled and Breslin had been concerned for the womanrsquos safety as she was under the influence of alcohol and in her bare feet.Sherf Thomas Welsh deferred sentence to next month for background reports.Breslin admitted struggling with the woman, shouting, swearing and acting in an aggressive manner, and attempting to push her into a vehicle and committing a breach of the peace at Wallace Avenue, Wallyford, on October , .

title: queues-outside-tesco-new-measures-put-place-stop-spread-coronavirus
story: Inside the store, yellow and black tape has been placed on the floor every two metres to give customers an idea of the space people need to give each other to stop the spread of the coronavirus.Tape is also used at checkouts, with customers advised to stay behind it until it is their turn to be served.A number of supermarkets are putting in similar measures to help people shop safely during the coronavirus outbreak.

title: coronavirus-childrens-hubs-key-workers-children-now-open-east-lothian
story: Schools across Scotland are now closed for an indefinite period due to the coronavirusoutbreak.Childrenrsquos hubs have been opened by East Lothian Council in each school cluster group, initially for youngsters whose parents have been identied as key workers.The local authority contacted eligible families on Tuesday to confirm a place at one of the hubs was available.The scheme is expected to extend to other parents who are key workers but do not come under category one ndash health and social care workers supporting the NHS response to Covid- ndash from today.A council spokesperson said: ldquoAt this stage, we have offered about  places across the six childrenrsquos hubs.ldquoWe will be moving to phase two of allocation of places where we may be able to allocate additional places. This will be confirmed in due course.Each hub is being overseen by a leadership team including a headteacher, supported by teaching, other specialist and support staff.At the early stages, hubs will be open from am until pm, with extended day provision being planned from next week.Food will be provided to children at the hubs, with free school meals for all eligible children also being distributed from them.The childrenrsquos hubs have opened at the following schools: Dunbar Primary School St Maryrsquos Primary School Haddington Primary School Law Primary School, North BerwickPreston Tower Primary School , PrestonpansSandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School, Tranentand Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School, Musselburgh.Parents had until Monday tea-time to register their child for a place in the hubs and education officials then began going through applications to identy those eligible.Meanwhile, thousands of youngsters have logged into the Google Classroom digital app to work remotely from home, with hundreds of classes and teachers available to them.Lesley Brown, East Lothian Councilrsquos education chief operating officer praised the commitment of pupils and staff to working online, saying: ldquoIncredible working is going on across all of East Lothian to support our young peoplersquos learning.She added: ldquoIrsquom very grateful to everyone in our school communities for their support in recent days. Although it is a challenging time for families and children will be missing their friends, we are heartened by the many stories of young people embracing remote learning with enthusiasm.ldquoIrsquod like to pay tribute to all of our education and school staff for their hard work and commitment.ldquoA huge amount of effort has gone into preparing resources for online learning and helping our school communities at this time.ldquoOur staff have responded very positively to our plans to introduce childrenrsquos hubs. This will provide continued access to learning or childcare for the children of key workers, enabling them to play a full and active part in supporting the local and national response to the coronavirus outbreak.ldquoWe have also been working with our private and voluntary nurseries and will be providing information on our continued support for young people in S- who had been due to be sitting exams. We want to enable these students to work remotely to complete coursework, with support in place from our teams so that sufficient evidence can be submitted to the SQA for certication purposes.ldquoAs dficult a time as this is, Irsquom proud of the collective effort which has gone into enabling us to be in a position to support the children and young people of East Lothian.Meanwhile, youth football club Preston Athletic YFC has opened its clubhouse in Prestonpans for children who cannot access the internet to connect free for homework. The club invited children along -pm during the week, with food and drink also being supplied to the youngsters.The club said:ldquoWe are opening the clubhouse Monday to Friday, -pm. We welcome children who do not have internet access at home to come along and use our internet free of charge to do homework they must bring their own tablet or laptop. We will give all children a free juice and biscuit, adults can have a free hot drink.One of the clubrsquos coaches has offered to produce soup and sandwiches for children who attend and Sugar Rush Creations has offered to provide all youngsters who are doing homework in the clubhouse with free popcorn.

title: tims-tales-graves-byres
story: A WEEK before the lockdown, I went for a walk with an old and close friend who was even then feeling isolated.We were very conscious of not going anywhere busy, and the need to avoid close proximity for ourselves as well. It was so strange not being able to give each other a hug, as we have always done over the past  years of our friendship.I chose a walk in which I hoped we would meet nobody , and we walked two metres apart. Despite our plan not to talk about the virus, we inevitably ended up doing just that, although not all the time.The walk took us to the site of the old Byres Kirk, just beyond Ormiston. As hoped, it was deserted, and so we entered.The eeriness of current events affected my behaviour. I walked around with my friend, carefully ensuring I touched nothing. The original kirk built here in  is long gone. It replaced an even older kirk, the remains of which are hidden in private woodland next to nearby Ormiston Hall not far from this site.The first kirk at Byres was eventually demolished and replaced by a neo-gothic building in the s. But after the opening of a new church in Ormiston in the s, Byres Kirk was finally abandoned and eventually demolished in the s.But the graves remain, including war graves, and there is also a headstone erected by Isabella Burns, sister of the famous poet, to the memory of her children.It was this headstone I had come to see. Isabella was the youngest sister of Robert Burns and she lived in Ormiston and Tranent for a while. In  she was widowed, with nine children, three girls and six boys. She set up a village school to help make ends meet.Itrsquos dficult to imagine what her le must have been like, but I think the fact she was part of Robert Burnsrsquo immediate family may have given her a status and a degree of respect most women were denied.I found the stone and was intrigued by it. Two of Isabellarsquos children are mentioned one of them, Edward, died at the age of  in China.ldquoChina  I said out loud to myself, wondering what he was doing there. I saw the date of his death: November , .Then it dawned on me: the Opium Wars! He must have been a soldier. I quickly Googled it on my phone and sure enough he was serving in a regiment there.I stood for a moment, thinking about the story behind this scant piece of information. The Opium Wars are not usually a prominent part of our history curriculum, although they should be. The British state went to war with China to safeguard the ability of British traders to sell opium to the Chinese, which resulted in  million addicts there. Itrsquos a dark part of our imperial history, and the fact that a nephew of Robert Burns ended up dead in China defending state-sponsored drug smuggling by Britain seemed horribly ironic and sad. But it also gave me a sense of the connectedness we all have. The decisions people make, especially those in power, affect the lives of others in ways we will never know or predict.The memorial headstone also had a later inscription which recorded the death of Isabella herself. She lived until she was  and died in . She isnrsquot buried in this graveyard, however, as she spent the last years of her le in Ayrshire and was laid to rest in Alloway Kirkyard.Such a web of le and connection, now mostly long forgotten, revealed by this one memorial stone.As I left, I noticed the trees: oak, sycamore, beech and yew. They seemed to grow out of lost human memory, asthey were now s of forgotten stories.On ourjourney to the car, we passed another memorial stone, this time to the Polish soldiers who had been based in Ormiston Hall in the s during the war. This too is now a time of memory fading, but not forgotten, as the flowers someone left revealed.We had succeeded in a walk seeing almost nobody, except a passing cyclist at the end. Next time we go on such a walk, spring will have arrived undisturbed by human footprints. Keeping people safe must be the priority.Although it was an unusually sombre walk, we found time to laugh and see the funny side of things too. We have to live le, make the best of our time, and the times, we have.And when we can once again regularly venture into naturersquos wonders, what an extra special gt it will seem.

title: sleep-boost-prestonpans-youngster-charity-dad-supported-lends-hand
story: Murray Scott, , liveswith broadcaster dad Mark,  mum Laura, , a supply classroom assistant at The Hub at Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School and sister Sophie, seven, a pupil at Prestonpans Primary School.Murray, who attends The Hub in Tranent, has a partially deleted chromosome which affects his development and brain.The condition also affects Murrayrsquos spine and hips he is unable to walk or talk, is doubly incontinent and is tube fed.Murray also has epilepsy and reduced vision, and for the first eight years of his le was unable to sleep through the night.Mark said: ldquoHe was born with it ndash itrsquos a chromosome disorder which neither of us [mum and dad] carries.ldquoHe would have been  months when we got the diagnosis ndash at that point he was one of  [sufferers] in the world.Murray is described by his family as a ldquoreally happy, content wee boy, and ldquoreally good natured. According to Sophie, he is ldquothe best big brother.Despite Murrayrsquos age, his parents said ldquohis brain has probably developed to that of a one-year-old, adding that he canrsquot pick things up and often does not know what to do with items hersquos given.It was Murrayrsquos physiotherapist at The Hub who recommended a sleep system: a series of blocks that help support his position while he sleeps.Murray had been sleeping with a large soft toy and pillow to prevent his leg getting stuck down the side of the bed.The youngster cannot adjust himself when he changes position during the night, which has been causing more damage to his spine and hips.It is hoped that the system, which can grow with him, will improve Murrayrsquos posture and reduce the need for surgery later on.Laura added: ldquoIt gives us a little bit of reassurance to know that hersquos not doing any more damage in his bed.Mark and Laura applied for funding to help purchase the sleep system from Cash For Kids ndash a charity for which Mark fundraised during his time working at Radio Forth.Mark said: ldquoIt is very dficult asking for charity help, especially when yoursquove raised a lot of money for that charity, but, at the same time, the sleep system costs about pound,.ldquoWe are delighted with it, itrsquos a huge help and makes a big change.Victoria Hendry, charity manager at Cash For Kids, added: ldquoWersquore absolutely thrilled to see what a dference the bespoke sleep system has made to Murrayrsquos quality of le.Donations to Cash For Kids can be made via cashforkids.uk make-a-donation

title: bid-transform-dance-schools-home-former-church-flats
story: Haddington School of Dance and Music is looking for alternative premises due to the spiralling costs associated with keeping its home at the former Newton Port Church up to standard.Continuing expense maintaining the building has led to a planning application for four flats being submitted to East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department by the business, which offers a range of dance classes, including hip hop, jazz and ballet, to a wide age group.A supporting statement included within the planning application highlights the dficulties being faced.It reads: ldquoThe necessary modernisation of heating, electrics and plumbing, together with roofing, prevention of water ingress and ensuring safety from falling masonry, has been a recurrent expense.ldquoThe owners are proud to have restored the building to the current level.ldquoWhat were thought to be initial major renovation expenses have, however, continued year on year.ldquoThe building is due for further major works of damp proofing and roof repairs to the extension.ldquoThere are several areas where water ingress has never been fully stopped.The building, which opened its doors as St Johnrsquos Church of Scotland in  before more recently being used by the congregation of St Maryrsquos as their church hall, has also been repeatedly targeted by vandals.Lead has ldquorepeatedly been stolen from the roof, while the sky lights have been ldquodamaged repeatedly.The document adds: ldquoIt has become clear that the ongoing costs of keeping the building wind and water tight, safe and up to modern standards for the current purpose are not a viable prospect for the future for the school.ldquoThe winter heating costs are prohibitive and the current school director cannot continue to run the school with accumulated losses.ldquoThe losses are entirely due to the upkeep of the building.ldquoThe current owner of the school is now considering how best to continue to provide the community amenity into the future.ldquoShe considers that this specialised service will be best provided in a modern, easily maintained studio space. That could take the form of an industrial unit large enough to house the theatre rigging and studio equipment.ldquoShe and her financial partners must now consider the best way to ensure the old church building is not left to fall into disrepair and are in talks with East Lothian Council planning department considering appropriate conversion projects.ldquoSeparately, she is seeking a more appropriate space to run the dance and music school.ldquoShe hopes to find a place where drop-off and parking are easier for parents, especially in the winter months.Two of the flats would be accessed from the rear, with two upper flats accessed by the existing double doors at the front of the building.

title: uk-lockdown-rules-deemed-essential-travel---can-drive-somewhere-exercise-walk-dog
story: Under new government guidance, people are allowed to go out once daily for exercise - but does this include driving to a beauty spot or park to run or walk your dog Here are the answers to some top questions.Can I drive to take my dog on a walk The current rules being enforced by the lockdown states that there are only four reasons you should be leaving your home:-One form of daily exercise - Shopping for essentials- Travelling to and from work- To fulfil medical needsNew government advice today addressesthe issue of driving further afield than where you live to take exercise.The guidancesays - please use the following guidance in order to stay safe:North Yorkshire Police have announced that they will be using checkpoints to stop vehicles and ask drivers where they are going.Assistant Chief Constable Mike Walker said: ldquoThe new and signicant restrictions announced by the Prime Minister on Monday evening spell out very clearly what each and every one of us must do to save lives.ldquoThe message is clear and the warning stark. Stay at home, save lives.A pamphlet handed out to drivers by the Avon and Somerset Police states: ldquoYou are entitled to exercise once daily. This should be by walking, running or cycling from your home address. You should not be driving to a location away from home to carry this out.With the police now being granted powers to arrest those who ignore lockdown rules, driving to a separate location to walk your dog or do some exercise is inadvisable.Are parks closed In the list released by the government, it stated: ldquoParks will remain open only for iniduals and households to exercise once a day.ldquoCommunal spaces within parks such as playgrounds and football pitches will be closed.The National Trust also announced that they are closing all of their gardens and parks as well due to the spread of coronavirus.Their statement said: ldquoWe have now closed all of our gated gardens and parks as well as our houses, cafes and shops to help restrict the spread of the coronavirus, and by the end of Tuesday  March, we will close all our car parks.ldquoWe believe it is important that people do not travel, and instead stay at home and observe social distancing measures.What is essential travel You should be aware of what the government defines as ldquoessential travel.After releasing the guidelines on social distancing, the government also said that people should avoid travelling unless itrsquos essential.The statement reads: ldquoEssential travel does not include visits to second homes, camp sites, caravan parks or similar, whether for isolation purposes or holidays.ldquoPeople should remain in their primary residence. Not taking these steps puts additional pressure on communities and services that are already at risk.Coronavirus: the facts by the World Health Organisation and the NHSCOVID- is a respiratory illness that can affect lungs and airways. It is caused by a virus called coronavirus.The outbreak started in Wuhan in China in December  and it is thought that the virus, like others of its kind, has come from animals.As this is such a new illness, experts still arenrsquot sure how it is spread. But, similar viruses are spread in cough droplets. Therefore, covering your nose and mouth when sneezing and coughing, and disposing of used tissues straight away is advised. Viruses like coronavirus cannot live outside the body for very long.The NHS states that the symptoms are: a dry cough, high temperature and shortness of breath - but these symptoms do not necessarily mean you have the illness. Look out for flu-like symptoms, such as aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose and a sore throat. Itrsquos important to remember that some people may become infected but wonrsquot develop any symptoms or feel unwell.Washing your hands with soap and water thoroughly. The NHS also advises to cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or your sleevewhen you cough or sneeze put used tissues in the bin immediately and try to avoid close contact with people who are unwell. Also avoiding touching eyes, nose and mouth unless your hands are clean.As of Monday,March , the prime minister has put the UK into lockdown and instructed all citizens to stay at home. People can only leave their homes to exercise once a day, go shopping for food and medication, travel for medical needs or to care for a vulnerable person, and travel to work onlyessential. Police will be able to enforce these restrictions.All non-essential shops will close with immediate effect, as will playgrounds, places of worship and libraries. Large events or gatherings of more than two people cannot go ahead, including weddings and celebrations. Funerals can only be attended by immediate family.Children of separated parents can go between both parents homes.Anyone with a cough or cold symptoms needs to self-isolate with their entire household for  days.The government has now instructed bars, restaurants, theatres and non-essential businesses to close and will review on a lsquomonth to monthrsquo basis. Schools closed from Friday,March ,for the foreseeable future, and exams have been cancelled.The over s or anyone who is vulnerable or living with an underlying illness are being asked to be extra careful and stay at home to self-isolate. People with serious underlying health conditions will be contacted and strongly advised to undertake "shielding" for  weeks.For more information on government advice,check their website.You should now avoid public places and any non-essential travel. Travel abroad is also being advised against for the next  days at least, and many European countries have closed their borders.Donrsquot go to your GP but instead look online at the coronavirus service that can tell youyou need medical help and what to do next.Only call you cannot get help online.Only call NHS you canrsquot get help online and feel very unwell. This should be usedyou feel extremely ill with coronavirus symptoms. If you have been in a country with a high risk of coronavirus in the last  days oryou have been in close contact with someone with the virus please use the online service.
