title: britons left dark covid  precautions returning peru
story: Two more British Airwaysflights carrying travellers from Lima touched down at Gatwick Airport on Tuesday morning, following those that landed at Heathrow on Monday.It comes as Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab announced that pound million would be set aside for charter flights to bring stranded Britons home from areas where commercial flights were no longer running.The Foreign Office said it was chartering three more BA flights to help British tourists still in Peruto the UK, with the first flight departing Lima on Sunday.It will also charter domestic flights from Cusco and Arequipa to Lima so that UK nationals can transfer to the London-bound flights.Arriving at Gatwick, Alice Nuttall, , from Nantwich, said: ldquoIt feels weird, I burst into tears when I walked through ndash wersquove been trying to get home for so long.ldquoWersquore assuming, because we had to fill in our contact information on this formhellip that wersquoll get contacted regarding [coronavirus].ldquoWersquove been told we need to pay pound for the repatriation flight by the Government.ldquoThey havenrsquot really advised us on anything , we havenrsquot been screened or anything, added her friend Ellie Durrant, .Ms Nuttallrsquos father John Nuttall, , said that the women and their families would be taking ldquosensible steps following guidance from Public Health England.ldquoTheyrsquoll self-isolate for  days and obviously follow the rest of the Government advice, he said.Relatives gathered at international arrivals in the terminal building, maintaining a two-metre distance, but many embraced their loved ones as they came through the gate.Other travellers expressed disappointment at being forced to come home early and said that they had not been given any clear instructions or extra precautions after arriving back in the UK.ldquoItrsquos a bit strange to be home ndash I was expecting to be travelling for another two-and-a-half months, said Anna-Lucia Strike, , from Chiswick in west London.ldquoI havenrsquot been told anything about what I should do now. I know the rules that are here in the UK but apart from that we havenrsquot been told anything extra.ldquoWersquove been pretty left in the dark, said Drew Jones, , from Essex.ldquoWersquore going straight into isolation I think, donrsquot really have much to do at home or at workhellip totally mixed emotions. vw,vw,px, px"Ellis Clarke and Drew Jones at Gatwick ldquoAfter two weeks we were locked down in a hostel, itrsquos bitter sweet, said his friend Ellis Clark, .ldquoIrsquom glad Irsquom out of that hostel but Irsquom quite bummed that I didnrsquot get to finish what I planned.Tuesdayrsquos repatriation flights came as BA announced that it will temporarily suspend all flights from Gatwick.On Monday, Luton-based carrier easyJet grounded its entire fleet of  aircraft as the aviation industry continues to struggle with the collapse in demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Britons  uleft in the dark u on Covid- precautions after ing from Peru article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: psni pauses legacy investigations preparation coronavirus surge
story: Simon Byrne has also announced the introduction of spit and bite guards for some officers on the frontline.The chief constable announced the temporary changes in a video posted on the PSNIrsquos Twitter feed on Tuesday.An update on temporary changes to @PoliceServiceNI operations as part of the response to #COVID, the service will continually update @NIPolicingBoard on our procedures and work with @PONIPressOffice to enhancepublic confidence. Please #StayHomeStaySafehttps:t.co cpvmKqHbxGmdash Simon ByrneMarch , He said officers and staff working on legacy were being transferred to bolster numbers as police worked to resume normal service amid the pandemic.Mr Byrne said that over the last weekend officers dealt with more than , calls which included domestic abuse incidents and missing people.ldquoWe have taken the decision to temporarily suspend all legacy investigations and release the officers and staff to provide immediate resilience to the PSNIrsquos critical policing s, he said.ldquoWe of course understand that this will be dficult for the families that have lost loved ones and itrsquos important to say that we recognise the continuing distress this decision will cause to many people who have suffered as a result of the Troubles.ldquoThis is a temporary measure and we will keep our decision under review as the current situation develops.The PSNIrsquos legacy unit is dealing with more than , unresolved cases.The chief constable also announced that spit and bite guard equipment was being made available to some officers for their protection.There have been several incidents of police officers being spat or coughed at by people claiming to have Covid-.The guards, made of mesh and plastic and placed over the head of a person who is threatening to spit or bite officers, were to be deployed in custody suites, it was announced last week.Mr Byrne said their use will be in line with human rights, videoed where possible, and the circumstances referred to the Police Ombudsman.ldquoGiven the unique and exceptional circumstances we face, I intend to make spit and bite guard equipment temporarily available to those dedicated Covid officers and those using cell vans, as well as people working in custody suites, he said.The representative body for police officers, the Police Federation, described the redeployment from the legacy branch as ldquounavoidable and understandable. vw,vw,px, px"Police Federation chairman Mark Lindsay Chairman Mark Lindsay said the redeployment will provide ldquomuch-needed resilience.ldquoI fully understand that for many victims of terrorism who seek information and closure, this will be a disappointing development.ldquoHowever, when the PSNI needs to maximise the number of officers for duty during this Covid- crisis, this decision is both understandable and unavoidable, he said.ldquoThis doesnrsquot mean that examining cases from the past will be forgotten. It simply means that the policing pressures of the here and now are so demanding that it requires the redeployment of all available officers.ldquoThis redeployment will provide much-needed resilience. Of course, what it also reflects is the fact that we are seriously under-resourced by several hundred officers and at this critical time, this glaring shortcoming is exposed..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: PSNI pauses legacy investigations in preparation for coronavirus surge article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"Comments are closed on this article. -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: duo spend isolation recreating famous looks mary poppins sir elton john
story: Freelance photographer Harriet Clare, , and dancer and performer Chloe Mead, , have found themselves isolating at Ms Meadrsquos parentsrsquo house in West Sussex with all work for the foreseeable future cancelled.Ms Clare told the PA news agency: ldquoWe donrsquot want to detract from the severity of the situation but hopefully it can be a welcome distraction and an inspiration for people to be creative at home.Miss Trunchbull pic vgTucGUHQMmdash Harriet ClareMarch , ldquoWhen at first all our work was cancelled it felt really disheartening as a creative to feel completely redundant and helpless towards the unfolding situation.ldquoEven though wersquore very aware that wersquore not on the frontline of Covid-, it has been nice to show how creativity is still important in these trying times.They have spent the last  days dressing up as dferent characters, including Miss Trunchbull from Roald Dahl novel Matilda and Sir Elton John.Ms Clare said: ldquoIt started one morning when Chloe put her hair up and it looked like Little My from the Moomins and so she decided to finish the look off and we sent it to some friends.Elton pics pic uUHHuYmdash Harriet ClareMarch , ldquoThey laughed so we thought it would be funny to ask people to challenge Chloe to dress up. The first suggestion was Captain Jack Sparrow and we laughed so much doing it we decided to continue asking for challenges.The costumes are a combination of the pairrsquos wardrobes, four costume boxes collated over the years and some inventive sewing.Ms Clare said: ldquoWe take it day by day and put forward options that people have suggested to us in an online poll. work on keeping your distancersquoReporter: Ciara MaguireEmail: ciara.maguire@strabaneweeklyTuesday  March  :Platform piece by Health Minister Robin Swann All across Northern Ireland, iniduals, families and communities are rising to the immense challenges created by social distancing. It needs to be stressed that the vast majority of people are doing the right thing. I want to thank them publicly and to acknowledge how tough it is to stay at home and keep your distance from others. However there has been a lot of attention on the small minority who have not followed the public health advice. It is essential that these tight restrictions are rigorously maintained in the weeks ahead. Quite simply, lives depend on it. So, let me appeal to everyone not to slip back into old habits. Any signs of complacency and impatience must be strongly resisted. Our actions now will impact on the spread of coronavirus in future weeks. Don’t lose heart or think the measures aren’t working just because of the current numbers and trends. What we are doing now is aimed at future weeks – slowing the spread of the virus and flattening its peak by drastically reducing human contact. That’s how we protect each other and protect our health service. We all have to stick with it, to get through this together. I make no apology for re-stating the vital advice once again. Stay at home. Please. Only go outit’s absolutely necessary and,you do, make sure you keep your distance from others. Wash your hands, thoroughly. When you sneeze or cough, use a tissue and then dispose of it – catch it, bin it, kill it. As a prominent doctor said in recent days, we can all be heroes. When we get through this as a society – which we will – you will want to look back and say you played your full part in fighting back against COVID-. I know very well the anxiety being felt across the community. I’m feeling exactly the same way - as a husband, a father and a son. But we have grounds for hope and positivity, alongside the deep apprehension. Social distancing will make a major dference –we keep doing it right and doing it together. Let’s take heart from the way people from all walks of le are coming forward to provide essential help. Our HSC workforce appeal is seeking new recruits to our health and social care workforce during the pandemic. Within a few short days of the appeal going live online, more than , people had signed up to register their interest in taking on roles. And there is large scale community-level volunteering going on, helping older and other vulnerable people cope during these dficult times. The Department for Communities is playing a key role in this area. When we look back, I hope we will remember how this crisis brought out the best in us how neighbours and strangers alike stepped up to help their fellow citizens in a time of grave need. When this is over, we will have a lot of rebuilding to do. Grief-stricken families, shattered lives, the economic and social fabric of society permanently altered.
